  physical_appearance: This is a three-piece uniform consisting of a turquoise A-line skirt
 jacket
 and a batik-print blouse. The latter is short-sleeved
 and collared; ending with a narrow bow where the top button usually is. Pocketed

  sgcool_label_text: This three-piece uniform belonged to a former Singapore Airlines ground hostess.  It consists of a turquoise A-line skirt that was coordinated with a short-sleeve collared blouse with a narrow bow in batik print design.  The uniform was designed by French couturier Pierre Balmain
 and was first unveiled in 1968 when Singapore Airlines was still part of Malaysia-Singapore Airlines (MSA).  Balmain’s choice of batik print for the uniforms of both cabin crew and ground staff was a means for SIA to assert Malayan identity and hospitality. The batik print design consists of brightly-coloured floral motifs and a colourful border resembling the sawtooth motif that runs along the edges of these uniforms.  A label stating the name of the tailor for this uniform
 “Lilian’s 108-A Orchard Road
 Tel: 377626” in on the jacket and blouse.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a three-piece uniform consisting of a turquoise A-line skirt, jacket, and a batik-print blouse. The latter is short-sleeved, and collared; ending with a narrow bow where the top button usually is. Pocketed, the jacket has the Singapore Airlines logo minted on it.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Pierre Balmain (Firm)  Corporate image Identity  Floral decorations  Uniforms  Malaysia-Singapore Airlines  Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This three-piece uniform belonged to a former Singapore Airlines ground hostess.  It consists of a turquoise A-line skirt that was coordinated with a short-sleeve collared blouse with a narrow bow in batik print design.  The uniform was designed by French couturier Pierre Balmain, and was first unveiled in 1968 when Singapore Airlines was still part of Malaysia-Singapore Airlines (MSA).  Balmain’s choice of batik print for the uniforms of both cabin crew and ground staff was a means for SIA to assert Malayan identity and hospitality. The batik print design consists of brightly-coloured floral motifs and a colourful border resembling the sawtooth motif that runs along the edges of these uniforms.  A label stating the name of the tailor for this uniform, “Lilian’s 108-A Orchard Road, Tel: 377626” in on the jacket and blouse.
